parts.text: A hair dryer contains three heating elements represented by resistors. The figure below shows the circuit diagram for the heating elements in the hair dryer. Complete the sentence: The three resistors are connected in _______________ with the power supply.
Which switch must always be closed for the hair dryer to work?
Which switches must be closed for the hair dryer to work at maximum power output?
markScheme: 1 mark: Answer: C — S1, S2 and S3

parts.text: Write down the equation which links energy transferred (E), power (P) and time (t).

The heating elements have a maximum power output of 1200 W. The energy transferred to the heating elements to reach normal operating temperature is 3600 J. Calculate the time taken for the heating elements to reach normal operating temperature at maximum power output.
The hair dryer has LEDs to indicate the power setting. What is the circuit symbol for an LED?
markScheme: 1 mark: Answer: A — LED symbol (triangle with arrow pointing away)

parts.text: A student investigated how the current in a circuit varied with the number of identical lamps connected in parallel. Figure 1 shows the circuit with three identical lamps connected in parallel. Figure 2 shows the results. Complete the sentences. Choose answers from the box. Each answer can be used once, more than once or not at all.
segments: As the number of lamps increased, the current
. As the number of lamps increased, the total resistance of the circuit
. As the number of lamps increased, the potential difference across the battery

parts.text: When there were three lamps in the circuit the ammeter reading kept changing between 0.35 A and 0.36 A. What type of error would this lead to?

Figure 3 shows a circuit with five ammeters and three identical lamps connected in parallel. Table 1 shows the ammeter readings. The total current from the battery is measured by ammeter A1. Each lamp has the same current flowing through it, measured by ammeters A3 and A4. Complete the table to show the readings on ammeters A2 and A5.
The resistance of one lamp is 15 Ω. The current in the lamp is 0.12 A. Calculate the power output of the lamp. Use the equation: $P = I^2 \times R$

A student investigated how the total resistance of identical resistors connected in series varied with the number of resistors. The student used an ohmmeter to measure the total resistance. The diagram below shows the student's circuit with 3 resistors. Table 1 shows the student's results for 3 resistors in series. Calculate the mean resistance of 1 resistor.

tables.caption: Resistance readings for 3 resistors in series

parts.text: What was the resolution of the ohmmeter the student used?
How do the results show that the student's measurements were precise?
options: The measurements are grouped closely together.
markScheme: Answer: B – The measurements are grouped closely together

parts.text: The graph shows the results of the investigation. How do the results show that the total resistance is directly proportional to the number of resistors?
options: The results give a line with a positive gradient.
The results give a straight line that would go through the origin.
The results show a linear relationship.
markScheme: 1 mark: Answer: B — The results give a straight line that would go through the origin

parts.text: Predict the mean total resistance of 7 resistors connected in series. Use the graph.

Some resistors are connected in series with a battery. When more resistors are added in series, the total resistance increases. Complete the sentences. Choose answers from the box. Each answer may be used once, more than once or not at all.
segments: When the number of resistors increases, the potential difference across each resistor
. When the number of resistors increases, the current in the circuit

parts.text: Figure 1 shows a circuit diagram with two lamps and a battery. In which position could a switch be placed so that both lamps can be switched on or off at the same time?
In 30 seconds, 24 coulombs of charge flow through the battery. Calculate the current in the battery. Use the equation: $Q = I \times t$
There is a potential difference of 3.6 V across the battery. Calculate the energy transferred by the battery when 60 coulombs of charge flows through the battery. Use the equation: $E = Q \times V$
Write down the equation which links current, potential difference and resistance.

Figure 2 shows another circuit built by the student. There is a potential difference of 3.6 V across the lamp in Figure 2. The current through the lamp is 0.80 A. Calculate the resistance of the lamp.

A student built Circuit X and Circuit Y shown in Figure 3. The components used in each circuit were identical.

How would the reading on the ammeter in Circuit Y compare to the reading on the ammeter in Circuit X?
options: The reading in Y would be higher.
The reading in Y would be lower.
The readings would be the same.
markScheme: 1 mark: Answer: B — The reading in Y would be lower

parts.text: How does the total resistance of Circuit Y compare with the total resistance of Circuit X?
options: The total resistance of Y is greater.
The total resistance of Y is less.
The total resistance is the same.
markScheme: 1 mark: Answer: A — The total resistance of Y is greater

parts.text: A student set up the electrical circuit shown in the figure below. The ammeter displays a reading of 0.10 A. Calculate the potential difference across the 45 Ω resistor.

The battery provides a potential difference of 12 V and the ammeter reads 0.10 A. The circuit contains a 45 Ω resistor, a 60 Ω resistor, and a resistor labelled R, all connected in series. Calculate the resistance of the resistor labelled R.
markScheme: 1 mark: Correct calculation of total resistance: $R_{\text{total}} = \frac{12}{0.10} = 120$ Ω
1 mark: Correct subtraction of known resistors: $R = 120 - 45 - 60$

parts.text: A switch S is connected in parallel with resistor R in the circuit. State what happens to the total resistance of the circuit and the current through the circuit when switch S is closed.
markScheme: 1 mark: The total **resistance decreases** (closing the switch short-circuits R, reducing total resistance)
1 mark: The **current increases** (as total resistance decreases, more current flows)

parts.text: Figure 1 shows the graph of current against potential difference for a component. The resistance of the component increases as it gets hotter. What is the name of this component?

Figure 2 shows a circuit containing a 6 V battery. Two resistors, X and Y, are connected in parallel. The current in some parts of the circuit is shown. What is the potential difference across resistor X?
markScheme: 1 mark: **6 V** (in a parallel circuit, the potential difference across each branch equals the battery p.d.)

parts.text: In the parallel circuit with a 6 V battery, the current through resistor X is 2 A. Calculate the resistance of X.
The total current from the battery is 3 A and the current through resistor X is 2 A. What is the current in resistor Y?
markScheme: 1 mark: **1 A** (total current minus current through X: 3 - 2 = 1 A)

parts.text: The potential difference across resistor Y is 6 V and the current through Y is 1 A. What is the resistance of Y?
When the temperature of resistor X increases, its resistance increases. Tick one box in each row to show what would happen to each quantity.
markScheme: 1 mark: Potential difference across X — Stay the same (parallel circuit, p.d. equals battery p.d.)
1 mark: Current in X — Decrease (resistance increases so current decreases)
1 mark: Total current in the circuit — Decrease (less current through X, same through Y)

parts.text:
Figure 1 shows how two lamps may be connected in series or in parallel to the 230 volt mains supply. Figure 2 shows a variable resistor and a fixed value resistor connected in series in a circuit. Figure 3 shows how the reading on voltmeter V1 and the reading on voltmeter V2 change as the resistance of the variable resistor changes.

How could the potential difference of the battery be calculated from Figure 3?
parts.explanationPrompt: Give the reason for your answer.
markScheme: 1 mark: The p.d. of the battery is **shared** between the variable resistor and fixed resistor (accept: V1 + V2 = p.d. of the battery / p.d. is shared in a **series** circuit)

parts.text:
Use Figure 3 to determine the resistance of the fixed resistor, R.

The variable resistor can be adjusted to have any value from 200 ohms to 600 ohms.
parts.explanationPrompt: Give the reason for your answer.
markScheme: 1 mark: The p.d. of the supply is shared **equally** when the resistors have the **same value** (accept: ratio of p.d. is the same as the ratio of the resistance)

parts.text: Calculate the current through the circuit when the resistance of the variable resistor equals 200 Ω. The fixed resistor R = 600 Ω and the battery provides 12 V.
markScheme: 1 mark: Correct calculation of total resistance: $R_{\text{total}} = 200 + 600 = $ **800 Ω**
1 mark: Correct equation selected + correct substitution: $12 = I \times 800$

parts.text: Hair straighteners contain three heating elements connected in parallel, each with its own switch (S1, S2, S3). Figure 1 shows the hair straighteners. Figure 2 shows the circuit diagram for the hair straighteners. Each resistor represents a heating element. Switch S1 is in the main branch of the circuit that connects to the power supply. Why do the hair straighteners not turn on when only switch S2 is closed?
markScheme: 1 mark: There is a **gap in the circuit** / S1 needs to be closed to **complete the circuit**

parts.text: The hair straighteners have a maximum power output of 120 W. The energy transferred to the hair straighteners to reach normal operating temperature is 3.6 kJ. Calculate the time taken for the hair straighteners to reach normal operating temperature when operating at maximum power.
markScheme: 1 mark: Correct unit conversion: 3.6 kJ = **3600 J**

parts.text: Figure 3 shows the hair straighteners circuit with switch S1 closed, connecting one heating element. Switch S2 and switch S3 are then closed at the same time, connecting two more heating elements in parallel. Explain what happens to the power output of the power supply.
markScheme: 1 mark: The total **resistance** of the circuit **decreases** (more parallel branches reduce total resistance)
1 mark: So the **current increases** (lower resistance means more current for the same p.d.)
1 mark: Which **increases the power** output (more current at the same voltage means more power)
